Firstly just on Pacific Aluminum, my usual question is, I mean we've been waiting a while now, the aluminum market doesn't seem to be improving at all, and doesn't – and given your comments about subsidies, government interference to stop closures, it feels like it'll be problematic for a while longer, when do we actually see some resolution to what you're going to do with it? And then also, are you thinking about, given it's loss-making, some of its assets, will you be closing some of the assets within Pacific Aluminum?

And then I just wanted to talk – see if you had any thoughts on China? And you made some comments before about marginal costs, et cetera. The Chinese government has been very quick to support its local industries, cutting power towers to help the smelting industry, last week talking about introducing VAT rebates to help the steel industry out. The iron ore industry, as I understand it, has some taxes, it pays royalties in taxes. Do you think the risk is, or have you heard anything about whether the government may step in and lower the taxes on domestic iron ore to make them competitive with what's happening in international arena? Thanks.
Thanks. Maybe Guy, if you could tackle Pacific Aluminum and I'll tackle China.

Well I accept that it's true that we have not been able to sell this business yet. Though we're very focused on doing so and we have a number of different options as to how we might do it, trade sale, spin, possibly later on an IPO. I do accept it's not the easiest environment in which to do this, so what are we doing? Well we've put a new management team in, as you know, and they are focused on running this business in a very lean matter, without compromising, of course, safety or compliance, but in a different way than probably the normal rear attentive operations would be run, more along a private equity model. And we're pleased with the progress that's being made there.

In respect to closures, we're not looking at that at the moment, I don't think that there's any – it's certainly true that some of the businesses are challenged, but we're focused on trying to improve them through various actions. And a very good example of that was the recent new contract that Bell Bay obtained in Tasmania. So we're determined to resolve this through sale, and we're confident that we can do that, it may not be tomorrow. And we're not going to be pushed into accepting too low a value. We want to get a good value for these businesses.

Thank you. I think, Glyn, on terms of marginal costs, I just think let's focus on, because time's short, on iron ore. First of all, I think we generally have focused more on the private iron ore producers than the SOE iron ore producers, and if you look at the demographics of those private producers they tend to be pretty small, and they tend not to be – some are quite sophisticated, some are less – are very informal. They don't tend to be what I'd call big parts of an employment base or to the extent an SOE would be. And I think over the past five years or so we have seen, I think, a reasonable correlation between price activity and whether they come in and out of the market.

So we wouldn't envision that to be much of a different pattern as we go forward. If anything we have to recognize that grades are continuing to fall. We certainly have seen a number of industries in China; labor costs are continuing to rise. We are certainly seeing that as the renminbi gets stronger that also plays into this. So I think the premise of pricing being driven off of marginal costs, particularly driven around the demographics of private iron ore operations in China remains valid. Now, maybe we have room for one...
Could I clarify?
Sorry?
I was just going to – wanted to clarify something Guy said, if I could please.
Go ahead, Glyn.
Yeah, sorry. Guy, I just wanted to clarify, you said your preferred method is the sale of Pacific Aluminum, does that mean the specie distribution to shareholders is off the table?

No, it's not off the table. I didn't prefer any particular route, other than to say that we would – we are looking at selling it. There are more than one option as to how we might do it, and we're focused on that. We're fully prepared for that, and meanwhile, we're running the business as best, you know, in a very tough manner, and very keen to prepare it for that sale process. I'm not preferring one route of sale rather than another. It's all about value.
I think, Glyn, the focus is on ensuring that it can be run on a stand-alone basis, which gives us options for whatever commercial pathway is the most optimal.
Maybe if we have time for one more question. I do want to close off at 11 o'clock. It is now 11. Operator?
You have a question from Clarke Wilkins from Citi.
About when...

Hi. Yeah, just a couple of questions around CapEx, just in terms of sort of the 2013, where would you sort of expect CapEx to come out based on the current approved projects and given you do have some major projects sort of coming to an end outside of iron ore? I think Guy sensed earlier that CapEx wouldn't go any higher, but without approving additional projects, would you actually think that the CapEx essentially drop next year?

And secondly just in regards to Simandou, what's the sort of spend right there at the moment? And how long do you continue that spend rate without sort of clarity on the timing around the rail and the port? And when do you sort of have to make a decision to stop spending there and then wait for the government to catch up?

Thank you. I'll just tackle these both pretty quickly. I think as we said, and I think the slide showed, if we don't approve anything, CapEx drops in 2013 as compared to 2012. I hope you've got an appreciation that the burden for a manager to get approval on a new capital project is very, very high right now. There's not a lot of appetite to increase capital above current levels. As a matter of fact, I think Guy recognized that $16 billion probably represents a capacity limit, both in terms of, both financial resources, but also people resources and other capabilities. So that means that, I think, that again it's going to take quite an astounding project to get through the hurdles over that next 12 to 18 months.

I think in terms of the Simandou, I think we are continuing to do quite a bit of work on engineering. We're engaging with the government of Guinea. We're engaging with our partners on all that work. We're doing the site prep in terms of future camp areas. So we're laying all the groundwork.

We haven't given a spend rate per say, but I'd say that it is fair to say the activity on the ground that we're putting in is much, much higher than anyone else in Guinea. I'm clearly committed to see a rail built, but a rail built under the terms that we had agreed upon with the government of Guinea and with Chinalco over the past 12 months. So it is in the process for development.
With that, thank you very much. Some of you, it's getting late in the evening. Others, you might want to switch over to the Olympic channel. Thank you.
